subject: The Horrors on Pluto
event:
Mordor is on Pluto!  Who knew?

Okay, got to admit, I think it is really cool that some of the features New Horizons is finding on Pluto (our ninth planet, dammit!!!) and its moon Charon are being named Mordor and Cthulhu.  Who says science fiction and fantasy haven't arrived?  J.R.R. Tolkien and H.P. Lovecraft have entered realms previously reserved for Greek and Roman gods.

Those ice mountains they've found are very cool too, and clearly need to be named the Mountains of Madness.  And of course when New Horizons sails on, deeper in the black realms beyond the solar system and finds a sinister tenth planet, we MUST name it Yuggoth.  Especially if it is covered in fungus.  (Which would be mind-blowing).

I am disappointed that no alien ruins or black monoliths have turned up yet, but I don't suppose you can have everything.

So hurrah for JRRT, hurrah for HPL, and hurrah for NASA and JPL.  Nice to know they're fans.

comments.article: Yeah GRRM! I totally agree. I think that Pluto is pretty cool, whether or not it is a planet. Perhaps they should name a feature Valyria?
Not on Pluto.  Maybe on Venus.  Valyria was a place of flame and heat.
Don't get too excited about those names, George: they're unofficial, and I doubt they'll become official. It'd be really cool if they did, though.
comments.subject: They are just unofficial names

comments.article:
Actually, they're on the list of names already submitted to the IAU. I'm pretty sure both of them will stand up to the checking process.
http://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/naming-plutos-features-0713201520/
comments.subject: Re: They are just unofficial names
Re: They are just unofficial names

comments.article:
We already have a bunch of planetoids like Pluto George, Sedna, MakeMake, Eris, Haumea,Juno, and many many others, so many in fact that we can't name them all. We already have run out of greek and roman names, which is why the moons of Uranus are named after works of Shakerspeare and Alexander Pope!

Now keep writing damn it, I'm an astronomer on the making (Undergrad in exoplanetology/astronomy) and I want to be able to name an exoplanet after some of your characters!
comments.subject: On Pluto

comments.article: Is the heart-shaped protrusion on the surface a prophecy of victory for Stannis? :-)
Surely one of the mountains near the edge of the white heart (Tombaugh Regio, now) should be called Castle Black or Hardhome :)

I'm patiently waiting for NASA to find ruins that are clearly human in origin. How weird yet amazing would *that* be? "All this has happened before, and all of it will happen again."

But I suppose I'd be able to live with alien ruins or black monoliths too! ;)

> and finds a sinister tenth planet, we MUST name it Yuggoth

If you're going to consider Pluto a planet, you'd have to consider Ceres a planet as well (since it's bigger than Pluto and in the same vicinity), so there you'd have your tenth planet.

But astronomers think that there might be plenty more celesial objects in the same category as Pluto and Ceres out there, so you'll get your Lovecraftian (dwarf)planet after all :^)
Just to think 20 years ago Sci-Fi and Fantasy was considered a "Niche" thing, now we are mainstream, you had a great hand in that by the way George, you should be proud of that.
There should be a Mountains of the Moon somewhere (as a nod to the Grateful Dead, of course).

Yes! These images coming back are spectacular! and I definitely take your point regarding ancient mythology now being joined by more modern mythologies. Let's hope some names from Westeros & Essos join the mix!
'One does not simply walk into Mordor!... One needs a spaceship.'
Why is there no like button on LiveJournal?
As long as there is no Dark lord forging rings there I am alright with it being called that.
comments.subject: The Horrors on Pluto

comments.article: That is cool. I still think of it as a planet. It's said to actually cross Neptune's orbit in its slow seeming transit. In astrology it is considered the planet of transformation. Astronomically, it has it's own law of physics somewhat. Mordor and Cthulhu are perfect for them. I think you could be inspired to write a book or short story about them. Cheers.
comments.subject: Pluto

comments.article: Amazing to see writers of their caliber being immortalized like this, who knows. Maybe one day well have the Santa Fe quadrant of the R.R. Martin Galaxy or something like that:)

Hello! Your entry got to top-25 of the most popular entries in LiveJournal!
Learn more about LiveJournal Ratings in FAQ.

I recently visited McDonald Observatory in west Texas and learned why Pluto is technically not a planet, by our own little solar system's standards anyway. There's nothing wrong with being called a dwarf, dammit!!! I can hear them cheering "Halfplanet!! Halfplanet!!" across the peaks and valleys of Cthulhu right now. And you know that the Gobrin Ice would be a lovely moniker for the hellish road to Mordor, in a hellishly frozen sort of way. There are a billion Winters out there, and the sky...wait, no, interstellar space is the limit. I think.
They call Pluto half a planet.  What does that make the rest of them?
This whole thing is amazing! Science rules!!

It's pretty good isn't it? This exploration has made me staggeringly aware of how limited our technology is. As powerful and refined as our computers and radio communications are, the bandwidth is so relatively feeble that we'll have to wait 16 months just to download all of the data already captured.

Were you old enough to witness the Voyagers' encounters with Jupiter and Saturn? Those were some heady days. No one had seen anything like it. In those days it felt like we were ahead of the technological curve and we would learn everything.

Now not only does our Milky Way seems incomprehensible, but so too does our neck of the woods. I suspect it's more to do with my age. The young can always dream bigger and strive farther.

Hahaha! So cool :)
I read "The Whisperer in darkness" recently and then I knew about New Horizons and Pluto. I was like : "Noooo guys don't go!!! It's Yuggoth!!!!"😨
I always love to see you mention Lovecraft. When I write, most often I tend to keep two authors in mind, Yourself and H.P. Lovecraft (though H.P. got in the door first.)

Actually, Tolkien has already been present in the Solar System for quite some time. The mountains on Titan (the biggest Saturn's moon) are called after Middle-earth's mountains (there is Erebor Mons, Mount Doom and many others!). And not only Tolkien - the plains of Titan are named after planets from "Dune". There is Arrakis Planitia, Caladan Planitia... :)
comments.subject: There's more on Titan!

comments.article: The Applied Physics Lab (part of Johns Hopkins) and NASA were the ones behind New Horizons, not the Jet Propulsion Lab. I'm sure lots of fans exist at each.
comments.subject: APL not JPL - small correction

comments.upictitle: Mr Geddy Lee (though not really): monster
comments.article: The young mountains tell us why we didn't find the monolith. There's tectonic activity on Pluto, of a sort. We'll need to visit the planet, find where the monolith is buried, and dig it out.

I've been on such a Lovecraft kick lately...usually kicks in about once a year, so this is nice to see. Let's just hope we don't stumble upon any idiot flute players beholden to their Blind Daemon-Sultan. On second thought, lets really hope that happens.
comments.subject: Lovecraft

comments.article: At least they didn't name it "Carcosa".  Only some sort of hyper-obsessive fanboy would name a geographical location after Carcosa.
That's great news! I hope that if they find the sinister tenth planet, then it could be huge and cold so we could call it The Great Other
